I just realized that if I were president and could get advice from any modern day president (say from FDR on), I would probably want the advice of Richard Nixon and Bill Clinton more than any of the others. Working back -- George W. doesn't cut it, neither does his Dad. Reagan wasn't the brightest bulb in the room and when he got caught with Iran Contra it was obvious that he really didn't have any idea what was happening. Jimmy Carter's over analyzing had him standing still when he should have been moving. I have to admit I have a soft spot in my heart for Gerald Ford. He was the most humble president. He knew he was over his head. He knew he needed some smart guys around him. If I was going to have a beer with any recent president it would be Ford. But Nixon... damn, the guy was brilliant. OK, so he was a bit paranoid. In foreign policy that can be a strength. And Clinton to... the guy is smarter than anyone around now. Do if I wanted advice, those would be the two ex-Presidents I would want to hear from. Amazingly, they are also the most disgraced. Maybe Washington just doesn't like guys who are too smart.

I like Ike. As Supreme Allied Commander in WWII he possessed unimaginable power; each critical decision of his affected the lives of countless soldiers and civilians. When he assumed the presidency, he appeared disinterested in the political muscle he possessed as the most powerful man in the world. His advisors constantly needed to remind him of what influence he and his office were capable of. He preferred to use the Oval Office as a personal putting green, a perfect president for the prosperous post-war era. Yet history shows him on the right side of issues, such as the looming civil rights struggle which would engulf the country in the 60's.
 
 Trust the advice of a man who exercises his powers sparingly and judiciously.
